Later, Athena transforms Medusa's appearance, turning her hair into venomous serpents and her gaze to stone. Summary: Cassandra, gifted with prophetic visions, sees all possible futures when making decisions. She knows people will call her names like \"opportunist\" and \"whore\", but she wants more from life than a traditional fate. Cassandra asks Apollo for the gift of prophecy, knowing it may be selfish, but convinced he will leave her someday. In her visions, she sees a happy beginning with Apollo, their son's birth, and a darkening future as Paris arrives, leading to war, death, and destruction. She witnesses the fall of Troy, her sons' deaths, and her own brutal end at the hands of King Agamemnon after being claimed as a slave. Seeing the world's demise, including Apollo's rage and eventual death, Cassandra decides to change the course of events by hurting Apollo so badly that he will never forgive her, leading him to curse her in return. In the end, Apollo watches Cassandra die, feeling sad and hollow, with the truth dying with her, but promising to avenge her death.
(Major) Character Death Evidence: "And her fear was justified because one piece of a future later, she is holding her dead son in her arms"

Cassandra foresaw and tried to warn her family about the impending doom of Troy, including the deaths of her loved ones: Hector's body dragged by Achilles' chariot; Polydorus' body washing up on the shore; Polyxena being killed as a sacrifice; her father King Priam being killed in the same manner as his grandson Polydorus; and her own rape at the hands of Ajax the Lesser. After Troy falls, Cassandra is taken captive and awaits her fate along with other women of the city, including her mother who will be given to Odysseus, Andromache who will be given to Neoptolemus but end up marrying Helenus, Polyxena who died before being given as plunder, and Helen who will return to her husband. Cassandra herself will be given to Agamemnon, who will rape her, and she will bear him twins before he is murdered by his wife Clytemnestra in revenge for the murder of her daughter Iphigenia; Clytemnestra will then kill Cassandra with the same sword.
(Major) Character Death Evidence: "He will bring me to his wife, who schemes with his cousin to kill him in revenge for the murder of her Iphigenia. She will ease him up with flattery before trapping him in a net in a bathtub, like a large mackerel caught by a fisherman, and will slay him with a sword."
